overview: The S.D. 2 version of the measure aims to consolidate and centralize government functions relating to broadband internet access. [12] A key amendment in this version is transferring the duty of collecting and posting certain broadband infrastructure notices pursuant to Act 151, Session Laws of Hawaii 2011, from the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs to the Broadband Office. [12] This version also inserts language to clarify the effect that the transfer of the Broadband Office will have on the continuity of rules, policies, and documents. [12]
appropriations: The legislative document appropriates $200,000 (HB934_SD2_.HTM.txt) out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii for fiscal year 2025-2026 to be deposited into the broadband revolving fund. [11] The legislative document also appropriates $200,000 (HB934_SD2_.HTM.txt) out of the broadband revolving fund for fiscal year 2025-2026 for the reimbursement of contracts executed by the broadband office. [11] An additional appropriation with a blank amount is included for fiscal year 2025-2026 for the establishment of an unspecified number of full-time equivalent digital navigator positions. [11]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Department of Budget and Finance (B&F) does not support the creation of any revolving fund which does not meet the requirements of Section 37-52.4, HRS, which includes the capacity to be financially self-sustaining. [10] [10] Regarding H.B. No. 934, H.D. 1, S.D. 1, B&F states it is difficult to determine whether the Broadband Revolving Fund would be self-sustaining. [10]
agency_impact: The Department of Business, Economic Development and Tourism states that the Hawaii Broadband and Digital Equity Office (HBDEO) has provided steady leadership in state broadband and digital equity and that DBEDT will continue to collaborate with the Office. [10] [10] The Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs requests an amendment to consolidate the duty of collecting and posting broadband infrastructure notices pursuant to Section 2 of Act 151, SLH 2011, from the Department to the HBDEO/Broadband Office. [10] [10] The Office of Enterprise Technology Services notes it will incur additional operational and administrative costs associated with moving HBDEO’s staff and services under its division. [10]
policy_impact: The measure has been amended to transfer the duty of collecting and posting certain broadband infrastructure notices pursuant to Act 151, Session Laws of Hawaii 2011, as amended, from the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs to the Broadband Office. [12] This version also inserts language that clarifies the effect that the transfer of the Broadband Office will have on the continuity of rules, policies, and documents. [12] Testimony was received requesting the removal of language that excludes the deployment of broadband infrastructure for the provision of retail service, arguing that it could prevent small, innovative projects in remote, unserved or underserved communities. [10] [10]
revenue_sources: The Department of Budget and Finance states that as a matter of general policy, it does not support the creation of any revolving fund which does not meet the requirements of Section 37-52.4, HRS, including the capacity to be financially self-sustaining. [10] [10] Regarding this bill, the department finds it is difficult to determine whether the Broadband Revolving Fund would be self-sustaining. [10]
six_year_fiscal_implications: According to testimony from the Office of Enterprise Technology Services (ETS), the HBDEO’s original request in the upcoming fiscal 2025-2027 biennium budget was based on a current budget of $360,000 (HB934_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_04-01-25_.PDF.txt) to fund four staff and operating expenses. [10] The testimony indicates HBDEO has been operating with essentially no operating expenses for the past two fiscal years. [10] The HBDEO had asked for $777,090 (HB934_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_04-01-25_.PDF.txt) for FY 26 with $452,302 (HB934_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_04-01-25_.PDF.txt) for personal services, and $324,788 (HB934_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_04-01-25_.PDF.txt) for other expenses. [10] ETS asks that the HBDEO be funded with this amount in the FB2025-2027 biennium budget. [10] ETS also states that without proper funding, moving the HBDEO to DAGS-ETS would negatively impact critical services. [10] The S.D. 2 version appropriates $200,000 (HB934_SD2_.HTM.txt) in general revenues for FY 2025-2026 to be deposited into the broadband revolving fund. [11] It also appropriates $200,000 (HB934_SD2_.HTM.txt) from the broadband revolving fund in FY 2025-2026 for the reimbursement of contracts executed by the broadband office. [11] ETS will also incur additional operational and administrative costs associated with moving HBDEO’s staff and services under its division. [10]
capital_expenditure_impact: Testimony from the Waianae Coast Comprehensive Health Center expresses concern with language in the bill under the Broadband Revolving Fund for "Supporting broadband projects, excluding the deployment of broadband infrastructure for the provision of retail service". [10] The Center requests the removal of the exclusionary language to restore the bill’s original intent, arguing the added language conflicts with the State’s objectives and policies. [10] Other testimony claims possible interpretations of this language could prevent even small, innovative projects in remote, unserved or underserved communities. [10]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: Testimony from the University of Hawai‘i supports the establishment of the Hawai‘i Broadband Revolving Fund to ensure funds are used to support long term sustainability of the state's broadband infrastructure assets. [10] However, the Department of Budget and Finance states that it is difficult to determine whether the Broadband Revolving Fund would be self-sustaining. [10]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The bill has been amended to S.D. 2, which transfers the duty of collecting and posting certain broadband infrastructure notices pursuant to Act 151, Session Laws of Hawaii 2011, from the Department of Commerce and Consumer Affairs to the new Broadband Office. [12] This version also adds language clarifying the continuity of rules, policies, and documents after the transfer. [12] New testimony from the Department of Budget and Finance expresses concern over the long-term self-sustainability of the proposed Broadband Revolving Fund. [10] Additional testimony provides more detailed opposition to the bill's language excluding the use of the revolving fund for the provision of retail service infrastructure. [10] [10]
